awd_titl_txt: RESEARCH INITIATION AWARD: Investigating a new Generation of Assistive, Innovative Technologies (GAIT) for balance rehabilitation
awd_abstract_narration:
Research Initiation Awards provide support for faculty at Historically Black Colleges and Universities who are building a research program. It is expected that the award helps to further the faculty member's research capability and effectiveness, improves research and teaching at her home institution, and involves undergraduate students in research experiences. The award to the University of the District of Columbia has potential broader and societal impact in a number of areas. The project seeks to explore a creative, novel, and potentially transformative sensory aid for elderly stroke survivors with the capacity to revolutionize rehabilitative and balance aid paradigms currently used. Undergraduate students will gain research experiences and are actively involved in the project.

The overarching research goal is to obtain new scientific knowledge on the effects of a non-mechanically stabilizing cue using fingertip or light touch, as well as a multidirectional partial bodyweight support (NaviGAITor) aid, for balance rehabilitation of elderly participants who are stroke survivors. Participant standing balance, gait, functionality and multisensory reweighting, as well as how the visual, somatosensory, and vestibular sensory systems adapt to added sensory information to yield a postural response, will be assessed. The potential of utilizing light touch to serve as a long-term, permanent rehabilitation aid for elderly participants is a radically different approach than devices and methods currently used. Further, the research will investigate a distinctive NaviGAITor system that allows for multidirectional range of motion, as opposed to the traditional with-treadmill or straight-path walking partial bodyweight support approaches. The knowledge resulting from this research has the potential to benefit society in that it ultimately aims at reducing falls in elderly stroke survivors.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

inst.inst_name: University of the District of Columbia
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of the District of Columbia

por.por_cntn:
With increases in average life expectancy, the importance of training methodologies towards good balance and preventing falls has significant societal relevance. The merit of this Research Initiation Award, Investigating a new Generation of Assistive, Innovative Technologies (GAIT) for balance rehabilitation (or NSF “GAIT” project), was the advancement of scientific knowledge on the effects of sensory (modifying touch and vision) and NaviGAITor robotic training on stance, gait, and mobility for people ranging from 60 to 80 years old. It was observed that sensory and robotic training could improve balance performance in aging healthy individuals and survivors of stroke. However, interestingly, balance confidence a subset of aging stroke participants was observed to be unrelated to improvements in their balance performance. Due to its simplicity and ease of access, sensory training may have future implications towards the ability of aging participants to balance-train in home-based settings. 

 

This NSF GAIT project led to the creation of never-before biomedical engineering research tied to aging balance, and human performance research in general, at the PI’s institution. This project furthered the infrastructure of the PI’s then newly erected laboratory, the Center for Biomechanical & Rehabilitation Engineering (CBRE) which opened in Summer 2015.  During the project period, the PI produced 39 publications (2 submitted, 37 published) most of which were tied to the NSF GAIT project.  Publications included topics such as: postural control in aging adults (gait and balance strategies), biomechanical analysis of aging balance pre and post sensorimotor exercises, investigating the relationship between balance confidence and balance ability in older adults, and multidirectional overground robotic training of balance in older adults.  Aside from key research findings, human subject research training and professional development of numerous females and/or underrepresented minority undergraduate research assistants at the University of the District of Columbia, a historically black college and university (HBCU) and the only public institute of higher education in Washington, DC, was an important impact. Undergraduate research assistants were key contributors to the NSF GAIT project, and many of the PI’s publications involved them as co-authors.  Further, tied to the NSF GAIT project, the PI gave 19 invited talks in community-based settings (e.g., Montgomery Stroke Association meetings), institutes and universities, and also public settings (e.g., her Alan T. Waterman Laureate Lecture:Falls and aging — the need for biomedical solutions to a global problem).  

As a result of this NSF GAIT project, it created never-before interactions with, for example, MedStar National Rehabilitation Hospital, the United States Food and Drug Administration, and Walter Reed National Military Medical Hospital. Further, during the award period, several dozens of biomedical engineering researchers visited the PI’s CBRE to give presentations of their cutting-edge research to students, faculty and staff.  Other indirect outcomes (both led and directed by the PI) included the ABET accreditation of the new Biomedical Engineering program making the University the first HBCU with a distinctive ABET-accredited bachelor of science in Biomedical Engineering program and the design of a new, upcoming multi-laboratory facility (a Specialized Technological center for Assistive Rehabilitation (STAR) research) focused on biomechanics, gait & balance, and virtual reality rehabilitation, such that the University is poised to serve as a regional and national hub in these areas. Through the above works, in 2022 since the NSF Alan T. Waterman Award's inception in 1975, the PI was the first Alan T. Waterman laureate from a HBCU and first self-identified female of color recipient; the Alan T. Waterman award is NSF’s highest early career honor for scientists and engineers.

 


Last Modified: 04/07/2023
Modified by: Lara A Thompson
